sentences.sentence: By Daniel AbleserThe Rand Formula or "mandatory check-off" is a straightforward concept in labour law: employees in a unionized workforce must pay union dues.
It was born of an arbitration decision by Supreme Court Justice Ivan Rand that ended a 1945 strike against Ford in Windsor, Ontario.
Before Rand, unions could only collect dues from members on a voluntary basis and the employer did not assist in the collection.
The UAW sought to make union membership mandatory and have Ford collect and remit dues to the union.
Ford sought to keep union membership voluntary so as to limit the union's power.

Rand ultimately ruled that while membership would be technically voluntary, employees had to pay dues whether or not they chose to formally join the union.The Rand Formula has been adopted in unionized environments across Canada and also enshrined in labour laws that the Supreme Court of Canada has ruled constitutional.

Laws and collective agreements may notionally allow union members to conscientiously object on religious grounds and apply to the labour board for an exemption under which they pay an amount equal to the dues to an agreed-upon charity.
However, that option is rarely used.

Employees generally treat union dues as no different than income tax, EI and CPP source deductions.The concept that employees who receive benefits from collective bargaining cannot freeload is therefore well-founded.

On the other hand, forcing union members to fund political activity they do not support is wrong.Following Hamas's attack on Israel, CUPE Local 3906, which represents 3,000 McMaster University academic staff, posted on X (formerly Twitter) "Palestine is rising, long live the resistance" and shared a post glorifying the attack.

CUPE Ontario President Fred Hahn "liked" the CUPE 3906 post and shared his own support for the attacks on Israel, including a post that stated "From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free" - a well-known chant that in effect calls for Israel to be eliminated: from the Jordan River to the Mediterranean Sea.It might be argued that Hahn's actions were personal and not in his capacity as CUPE president.

But Hahn put that argument to bed when, after accusing Israel of apartheid, he noted "These are the positions that have been adopted by members of my union in CUPE Ontario for almost 20 years - and not only us - unions and progressive organizations around the world have done so.

"CUPE Ontario then doubled-down, putting out a statement that attacked Israel as an apartheid state, supported Hahn's and CUPE 3906's messaging and accused those criticizing them as trolls backed by the pro-Israel lobby.Hahn's claim that CUPE and its associated unions have long been involved in this type of political activism, particularly against Israel, is accurate.

In 2009, when led by longtime president Sid Ryan, CUPE Ontario pursued a ban on Israeli citizens working, or even speaking, at Ontario universities.Unions regularly endorse and support political candidates.
Generally, the beneficiaries are NDP and Liberal candidates, but in the 2022 Ontario election at least ten trade unions supported Doug Ford's Progressive Conservative government.
In whichever political direction such support is directed, however, it is financed by union members' contributions.That's not fair.
Union members should not be forced to fund political activism.

It ought not be a pre-condition of working at McMaster University that you fund CUPE Local 3906's radical endorsement of Hamas' attack on Israel, nor the political activity of union leaders like Fred Hahn and Sid Ryan.Terence Corcoran: The climate war heating up the bestsellers list(https://financialpost.com/opinion/climate-war-heating-up-bestsellers-list)Improve public health by swapping Big Tobacco for Big Vape(https://financialpost.com/opinion/improve-public-health-swap-big-tobacco-vape)Progress in economics isn't like progress in vaccines but it helps(https://financialpost.com/opinion/progress-economics-vaccines-helps)Unions should have to decide.
Either they limit themselves to purely labour activities, such as collective bargaining and grievances, and are entitled to mandatory check-off and employer collection of union dues.

Or they engage in whatever other activities they please but mandatory check-off does not apply to them so that employees do not have to be associated with views or actions they do not agree with.Daniel Ableser is a lawyer.
